page.title: 06Flora of Silverdale
page.content: Pastureland, saltmarsh, and woodland are the main features of this limestone area. The woodland trees include small leafed lime, spindle, buckthorn, alder buckthorn and yew. Jack Scout is the property of the National trust and overlooks the sea. There the noteable plants among the limestone flora are autumn ladies tresses, creeping St.John's wort, and storksbill. Old man's beard climbs amongst the hawthorn. Set amongst the woodland above Jack Scout are the gardens of Greywalls house. They have degenerated of late, but still contain plants of the once beautiful and well stocked garden. Towards Jenny Brown's Point, by the cottages, grows the plant Moschatel. Rustybacked fern is also found. On the edge of Leighton Moss, yellowflag iris and reedbeds flourish.
